content.text: Once upon a time, in a small village nestled between rolling green hills and a sparkling river, there lived a poor but honest woodcutter named Thomas.
Though he had little, Thomas was content with his simple life.
Every morning, he would rise with the sun, eat a humble breakfast of bread and honey, and set off into the forest with his trusty old axe.
He worked hard all day, chopping wood to sell at the market, and returned home at dusk, tired but happy.
One bright and sunny morning, Thomas went deeper into the forest than usual, searching for the tallest, strongest trees.
He swung his axe with all his might, and the sound of chopping echoed through the woods.
After hours of hard work, he had gathered a large pile of logs.
But as he bent down to tie them together, his hand slipped—and *SPLASH!* His beloved axe tumbled straight into the river below!
Thomas gasped and rushed to the water’s edge.
The river was deep and swift, and no matter how hard he tried, he could not see his axe beneath the shimmering surface.
He knelt on the bank, his heart heavy with sorrow. "Oh no!" he cried.
"That axe was my only tool! How will I feed my family now?
What will I do?"  Just then, a ripple disturbed the water, and a shimmering figure rose from the depths.
It was the River Spirit, a kind and wise being who watched over the waters.
She had long, flowing hair like silver threads and eyes that sparkled like the sun on the waves.
"Why do you weep, dear woodcutter?" she asked in a voice as gentle as a babbling brook.
Thomas wiped his tears and bowed his head.
"Oh, great River Spirit," he said, "I have lost my axe in your waters.
It was my only one, and without it, I cannot work.
My family will go hungry."  The River Spirit nodded thoughtfully. "Do not despair," she said.
"I will help you find your axe." With a wave of her hand, she reached into the river and pulled out a gleaming golden axe.
"Is this the one you lost?" she asked.
Thomas looked at the golden axe, its blade shining like the sun.
It was beautiful, far more valuable than his old one. But he shook his head.
"No, that is not mine," he said.
"My axe was plain and made of iron, not gold."  The River Spirit smiled and dipped her hand into the water again.
This time, she pulled out a silver axe, its handle carved with intricate designs.
"Is this the one?" she asked. Thomas admired the silver axe, but again, he shook his head.
"No, that is not mine either.
My axe was old and worn, with a simple wooden handle."  The River Spirit’s smile grew wider.
Once more, she reached into the river and brought up Thomas’s own iron axe, its blade slightly rusted and its handle worn smooth from years of use.
"Is this the axe you lost?" she asked. Thomas’s face lit up with joy. "Yes! That is mine!
Thank you, thank you!" He reached out to take it, but the River Spirit held it just out of reach.
"Wait," she said. "I am pleased with your honesty.
You could have taken the golden or silver axe, but you told the truth instead.
For your honesty, I will give you all three axes as a reward." She handed him the golden axe, the silver axe, and his own iron one.
Thomas’s eyes widened in amazement. "Oh, thank you, kind River Spirit!
You are too generous!" He bowed deeply, his heart filled with gratitude.
When Thomas returned to the village, he sold the golden and silver axes for a great sum of money.
With his newfound wealth, he bought a new house, warm clothes for his family, and enough food to last through the winter.
But no matter how much he had, he never forgot the lesson of honesty.
He continued to work hard, chopping wood with his old iron axe, and always told the truth, no matter what.
And so, Thomas lived happily ever after, his kindness and honesty bringing him more joy than gold or silver ever could.
